comments.commentBody: NAIL before GONG! That was my other something else before something else.  I also considered CAVING.

I got what BIG SPOON was referring to once I'd pieced tghe entry together, but I'd certainly never heard the term. Deb's link was fun though.

I don't get LOG ROLLS as clued at all. A post-solve Google got a bunch of stuff about helping disabled patients while they are in bed. Given that I am just about to go up to my incapacitated friend's house to continue fulfilling my responsibilities under power of attorney, I didn't feel like looking at that. There was nothing immediately obvious about any quid pro quo.
New to me too - so I had to look it up after - http://www.thefreedictionary.com/logrolling

This one seemed to run a little on the hard side for me, particularly because I didn't feel on the constructor's wavelength. There were two answers I flat-out didn't know, and that's rare for me at this point. One was LOGROLLS, as a synonym for quid pro quo, and the other was BIG SPOON. (I certainly know what spooning is, but to me, a BIG SPOON is what you eat soup with--as opposed to stirring your coffee with a little one.) The clue pointed to the general idea, but I'd never heard the expression.

Now some of you might find these gimmes, and others that I found easy, you might find less so. So I learned two things tonight.

As for Howard Hughes (the famous one), anyone else put RECLUSE first?

What about FORCE FEEDS for "Puts away under pressure"? True, it's not an exact correspondence, but same number of letters, and it seemed right at the time.

I'm tired of hearing--or thinking--about Julian ASSANGE. In my book, he's one of the world's biggest 58A.

Anyone put NAIL for GONG? And then doubt it because it sounded like a drunk reference?

CAVING for DESCENT before seeing that it was too short? And that a Spanish word wasn't going to end in a V? CEDE before--wait for it--CAVE?

Basic count for ONE TO TEN? Maybe better, basic scale?

Grain free here. Very few restaurants offer "clean" grain free menus.  Best options for this are at the high end. Since starting eating this way I feel great and won't go back to eating whatever but it does make me very hesitant to eat anywhere other than out of my own kitchen.

Really? In the NY Metropolitan area, skim milk is $2.15/gal at Costco or BJs. Eggs are now $0.99/dozen at Trader Joe's
And I pay about $2.20/gallon for gas. Cleveland more expensive than NYC? Who'd have thunk it?

Concerned Citizen, I agree with you about food prices being already high (I live in Chicago, a very expensive place to buy groceries, both because of the high food prices and the tax(es) on all grocery items). The probably temporary drop in milk and egg prices is of no benefit to me, since I don't buy either item.

I also agree with you that McDonald's is not inexpensive at all--for what they sell, I have found it high-priced for years (as a vegetarian, I don't eat most of what they sell, but I will buy French fries sometimes), and others agree with me. (I also agree with you about Walmart not being that inexpensive for what they sell; although not a Walmart shopper myself, I checked grocery prices while on an errand for a friend and was not impressed). I think another commenter mentioned almost-cold food: McDonald's on W. Fullerton off of Elston in Chicago, you are guilty of this (I thought I'd take the opportunity).

The kind of 1970s health-food cafes that I liked are long, long gone in the major metros (perhaps they survive in some college towns, but I wouldn't know), but except for occasional take-out, which may only mean a few baked goods, I think many Americans don't really have money to spare for eating out. The taxes alone are money that you will never get back. Many people just don't have the disposable income anymore.

A few years ago when fuel prices were very high all food went up tremendously. fuel is cheap now but the prices didn't go down by the same percentage.
I do the food shopping so I keep up with the increases and they have been steady.
We are on Social Security. It has always puzzled me why the federal government does not include the cost of food and fuel while computing the CPI. Then they tell us" no increase" because inflation is low.

I live in the Midwest; I have observed that ALL restaurants have increased prices about 20-30% in the last few years (2-3 years). Grocery prices were going up even before this.

It is true that egg and milk prices spiked last year, and have come way down since. But how long will that last? Milk was up to $4.30 a gallon and eggs at least $3.25 (and I am talking "conventional' and not organic!). It was scary. Not unlike $4 a gallon gas!

But did prices really moderate....or did the government intervene, so that people were in a "happy place" for the elections? I am suspicious each election cycle, no matter which party is in power! it's all too easy to do this on a temporary basis.

But groceries are MORE than eggs and milk, and restaurant prices have STAYED very high. 2-3 years ago, every fast food place had a "dollar menu" that was a huge bargain. Today, those "dollar items" are renamed "value menu" and cost $1.50 to $1.80 each. That is an 80% increase in 24 months! and if you have kids, and they want McD.....that's sticker shock.

Family style restaurants have gone up even more. There are no more $7.99 specials. Everything is well over $12, even salads and chicken dishes.

I can't speak for fancier eateries, as my budget rarely permits going to them.

I would  not call places like Chili's or Olive Garden "restaurants."  I'll only eat out where I can get better quality, were the food is such that it is a pain to make at home or I am getting hard core white table cloth service.  I am not a millennial but I say god bless em for trending towards making a decent home cooked meal as opposed to eating garbage.

Excellent point! one thing harming restaurants at all price points -- they now use pre-made foods (from off premises) and just reheat them.

You are paying sky high restaurant prices (and tips!) for LEFTOVERS.

For years now, fast food places have bins of pre-made burger patties or taco filling or fried chicken nuggets -- and just keep them under heat lamps! gone are the days when "fast food" meant "they fry it up to order for you" or cooking on a griddle or grill.

Frankly, the quality of even simple things like a burger or taco have gone WAYYY downhill. I am can't be the only one who has been served inedible garbage on my occasional trek to a fast food place. This also goes for family style places. I have read this is common even in FRANCE!

Restaurants are struggling with food costs, advertising, and higher minimum wages.....imagine when they have to pay $15 and health insurance. We'll be lucky if they open the can of dog food FOR us.

Having worked in a very nice French Bistro for 16 years, watching the restaurant scene in Los Angeles grow to what it has become today.. Here are my reasons why I prefer to cook at home: Value, experience, food handling, and...wine. Seldom do the stars come together dining out so that the experience transcends what I create at home.
:

40 years ago when I came here to Charlotte there wan't any where to eat out that wasn't a Greek owned truck driver place. The problem was that we were dry (no alcohol) After we allowed liquor by the drink things improved greatly.
But the best places are still small family owned places.
Two years ago a Polish couple opened a small place near me. They seem to be making it. We go there for a change of menu. Polish Hunters Stew with sauerkraut and pork in it. A plate of pierogies with one of each flavor. For dessert a pierogie stuffed with Nutella.
My favorite Chinese place is a 10X10 space at a local supermarket. Take out or use the market's tables. I have to travel 9 miles round trip so I plan it for when I am going shopping. The wife likes shrimp in lobster sauce. She saves the liquid part and cooks some frozen shrimp and makes another meal of it. It runs us about $25 for two with some add ons but the quantity is enough for a second meal. Six bucks a piece is reasonable to me.

"Only a fool like Donald Trump eats out constantly."

And it shows. Just look at him (or at that statue that pranksters put up all over the country). :)

Wendy's used to be known for its quality chili.  The last time I had it there, it tasted watered down (where's the beef!?) and as if it came out of a very large can.  No comparison to the taste and consistency of 5-10 years ago.

Dining out (in most cases, but not all, e.g. high end and ethnic places) is not worth the price. With the tremendous portions, it is not good for your health, either.

Fast Food has particularly gone downhill. I had a hamburger in a pub in London last year, and I could not believe how fantastic it tasted. It was simply because the beef was sourced from outside the industrialized U.S., and not full of antibiotics and other additives.

Years ago, I enjoyed a meal at McDonald's. Not anymore: it simply does not taste like anything recognizable. Wendy's created by Dave Thomas has gone downhill after it was bought by corporate raider Nelson Peltz. It is no longer, good solid Ohio fast food - it is leveraged buyout food. It tastes like it, and the service is inferior.

I still like In 'N Out in the west. It is family owned, and the people who work there give good, friendly service - probably due to their higher wages and health insurance.

Chains are usually inferior. You can make that stuff at home. A prime steak you can make at home, and not pay a la cart for the sides. Dim Sum, Korean or Thai - one goes out for those. A special occasion at a high end resort or Beard-award restaurant with a well known chef - that's good too.

Only a fool like Donald Trump eats out constantly.

Actually not true. I finally caved and got Blue Apron 2 weeks ago. The 2 person meal is approximately $10/ meal and for us, yields 4 meals.
I spent way more per week before this and threw out produce routinely at the end of the week (that's just my poor planning).
I now get chef-y meals with vegetables I may not have tried before and portions that are just right with no guilt about wasting food. I'm excited about cooking now and it's not the same boring food.

I'll give a plug for Blue Apron -- or any other meal home delivery -- which I have been using on/off for the past six months. It's a fun and easy way to try new recipes. Yes, I could find my own new recipe, go to the store and buy the ingredients for less cost, but I can try something different with unusual ingredients and not have to buy a large bottle of something I decide I really don't like that well and end up throwing out. Also I don't have to decided on a recipe (after a long day that's sometimes helpful!) and I don't have to go to the store -- a plus for me since I live out of town. I like that the ingredients are fresh and the meats good quality -- the overall quality of the meal is certainly much better than a fast and/or casual restaurant and the food much more interesting. I don't use Blue Apron weekly -- just occasionally as the menus appeal to me. I do end up adding some of their recipes to my regular cooking so in the end I do save money there. Bottom line for me it's just an option to augment home cooking.
I also wondered about the plugs for Blue Apron.The waste involved in packaging put me off all of those services.
Interesting information and hopefully true, but there were a lot of plugs here for Blue Apron, which I suspect is more expense than doing it yourself or even a fast-casual restaurant.
Ouch is right! Enjoy your waffle maker. -- I love mine, too.

Buy local - Buy fresh - you will beat or equal the restaurants in every case.

Seriously - how hard is this?

Richard Luettgen writes, "the value to society of a vote is inversely related to the ease of voting." Nonsense! Ease of voting is directly related to wealth and leisure, being able to take time off from your workplace and drive home to vote on a Tuesday, and having access to transportation and to knowledge about where to go to get what.
It is not true that poor people's votes are of less value. It is true that our increasingly greater ID restrictions are making it harder for poor people to vote.

It sounds just delicious and I am happy to come over to eat anytime you want me! :-)

However: you left off a lot of stuff. The cost (in time and travel and aggravation and waiting on line) of grocery shopping -- planning each meal (you can't eat the same 3 meals over and over every day!) -- putting away and properly storing the things you don't cook immediately -- AFTER you eat, the clean up, storing leftovers, washing pots and pans, loading and unloading the dishwasher, sweeping up, etc.

Anyone who just thinks "the time of actual cookery" is either naive, or has a live-in maid.

When I do eat out (I cook a LOT, but not always)....a big part of the draw is NO CLEAN UP. No clean up means "no arguing among adults, nor children about who has to do the unpleasant tasks of dishwashing, putting away, washing up pots or cleaning the stove".

It also means "everyone can order what THEY want and don't have to agree on one entree". For two compatible adults, this may not be a problem -- but a family? with 3 opinionated teenagers? or younger children with strong food preferences? or anyone with allergies or on diet? Oy.

"opinionated teenagers" - "strong food preferences" - food "allergies" - "diets"

None of these existed 65 years ago, and we were not allowed a say about what we ate, at home or out, yet we turned out fairly well after we all received polio shots. Kids today...

And if that beverage is wine, it's likely to be $9-12 per glass at moderate-priced places, plus tax and tip above that.  If you can cook at home, and enjoy it even somewhat, you can save some significant dollars.

These are meals we routinely make for 2 people

(1) Broccoli risotto w/arborio rice, fresh broccoli, gorgonzola & gruyere + mixed green salad with homemade dressing (vinaigrette or yogurt based dressing) = $3 per person

(2) Boneless pork chops poached in wine + orange glazed brussel sprouts + potato salad (new potatoes, onion & celery with dressing of homemade yogurt, lemon juice, white wine vinegar, garlic & dill) = $4.37 per person

(3) Cajun shrimp + herbed rice + green bean/artichoke/tomato/onion salad w/vinaigrette = $6.5 per person

None of these meals take more than 30-45 minutes to fix.

Desserts - if we bother - are

* hot raspberry (blueberry)(strawberry)(blackberry) souffles at 87 cents per person

* homemade gingerbread (mixes are awful)

* Grand marnier cookies w/Grand marnier glaze

* homemade ice cream - lemon, honey French vanilla, creme fraiche etc (so rich you can only eat an amount equal to 1/4 of a serving of an commercial ice cream)

* lemon blueberry pound cake

You can't get a cup of coffee and a cup of soup in a restaurant for $3-6.50!!

So why would I go to a restaurant and spend $25-35 + tip PER PERSON for a shrimp dish + salad + $5 beverage (total around $36-42 PER PERSON) that I can make for $6 -6.50 per person?

I'm not that stupid as to waste the money

(And I'm a far far better cook)

Seriously....you ordered and paid $18 for a place of spiralized zucchini?

That's some boldfaced price gouging! this is barely past summer, and zucchini is THE most prolific and cheap vegetable this time of year. I have neighbors literally crying and begging for me to take zucchini off their hands.

The actual cost of that "zoodle" dish to the restaurant was probably less than a $1 in food costs.

I had zoodles (spiralized zucchini) at a trendy local restaurant recently. The sauce was simple -- grilled vegetables and a roasted tomato sauce. The dish was small and cost about $18 before tax and tip. I left hungry. Now, I have a spiralizer and I make noodles at home in minutes.  It's easy to toss them with any kind of pasta sauce you like -- pesto, a jar of this or that, roasted heirloom tomatoes.  Make a little extra and you've got lunch the next day. And did I mention the parking is easy and the dress code casual? Doing it this way, you could feed the zoodles to an entire family for the price of one entree in an annoyingly trendy restaurant. What's not to like?

I've never seen any economics articles track this. There has been an EXPLOSIVE increase in the cost of all restaurants, from the humblest taco stand or McD to family places like Applebee's or Olive Garden -- and while I am not among the wealthy, I imagine the high-end places have raised prices even more so.

I'm not talking nickel increases; the costs at some fast food places have gone up 80%. Former 99 cent items are now $1.79. That's a HUGE increase for struggling, working families. And this is before minimum wage increases have really gone into effect in most areas. What then?

Sorry CC, but 99 cent items were - never - good food, even when the menu was only four items long.

Once that cheap/easy/high-volume menu stretched past ten items, it became unwieldy, inefficient, and unprofitable, but hung around as a loss leader due to management ineptitude.

When patrons started needing 5-10 minutes to decide on their orders, when waiting at the end of a drive-thru line that had no exit became torture... the 99-cent menu concept self-destructed.

The survivor is In-N-Out, or anyone else, who has a limited menu and a workable system.
The cost of eating out, everywhere, has gone up insidiously in recent years.  Rents and wages have caused this and people who like to eat good food are well advised to cook and prepare at home.
Food quality, traffic, parking, dirty looking and tasting food, big fatty portions, and loud and uncomfortable venues keep me home and happy cooking healthy food.

It's not an 80% risk.  It means that those who used these contraceptives are 80% more likely than those who don't.  A little less than twice the risk.  So, for example, if 10 out of 1000 women who didn't take the hormonal contraceptives became depressed, 18 out of 100 who did would similarly become depressed.  A significant increase, to be sure, but still not a huge number.

But when people are asked "why do you continue to live in NYC, despite the very high rents and taxes"....the answer is very often, "all the restaurants and things to do!"

Yesterday was one of those "The Hunt" articles about a young couple looking for a new apartment, and they rejected the idea of their own ENTIRE HOUSE in a lovely leafy suburb....vs. a tiny city apartment....because "the suburb only had four restaurants" and they enjoyed eating meals out.

Yes, I wonder too, why someone would pay $9 for a sandwich, when when can
go to a grocery and get a roll and salmon (your choice) for a fraction of that.

And I cannot resist pointing out the huge gap in the price of wine: I recently paid $12 for a glass of prosecco in an average restaurant, while the shop next door sold a bottle for $11!!!

And I am tired of hearing about the high rents! Value is the thing!

I live in NYC. It amazes me sometimes how many restaurants, food stands, delis, and grab-and-go spots manage to stay in business -- even with the population here -- given the prices, and I'm also amazed at how many people routinely pay 300-500% more than grocery store prices when they buy things like yogurt on the go from places like Starbucks, etc. I make a decent salary and it pains me when I don't bring my lunch and I wind up having to fork over close to $8 for a basic turkey sandwich from a random deli. Total waste of money. I love trying restaurants but I need to feel like I'm putting the money towards something unique that I can't just make at home.

A food budget in NYC can actually be quite reasonable if you plan, grocery shop, and watch sales. I routinely buy things like cereal, snack foods, paper towels, cleaning products and other commercially packed goods from CVS because they run specials on those items frequently. The rest comes from grocery stores like Trader Joes, Fairway, and Whole Foods while eschewing other grocery stores and bodegas that will definitely upcharge (yes, Whole Foods wins in a fight against Gristedes). Overall, I haven't found grocery bill much worse than shopping in the suburbs. It's the rent that kills here!
Apparently butter is a restaurant chef's best friend.....so a film of butter coats everything and it all tastes like butter

The food at most restaurants isn't very good, there is something about it that all tastes the same, no matter what you are eating.  Cooking at home isn't difficult and simple foods with quality ingredients taste better than you can get at all but very high end restaurants.  If you garden, even better, now you have the freshest of foods that need nothing but a touch of butter or a dash of dressing.

Don't ignore the impact of beverage selection and pricing on the decision to eat at home. The wine lists at all but the best restaurants consist of current-release bottles at three times the retail tab. I'd rather cook at home and raid the wine cellar for a bottle that's properly aged and arrived appropriately priced.
Hold on!  In the midst of our long, dark, political nightmare, some good news!

My Father and I installed institutional kitchens. The things we've seen would gag a maggot. We've worked in most of the most famous hotel kitchens in Miami and many I swore I would never eat at after I saw the lack of cleanliness where you can't see unless you are doing a kitchen rehab.
My Uncle worked in a pork store in Brooklyn when I was a boy. He'd bring me in to help clean sometimes. Trust me. You don't want to watch sausages made.
In my teens I worked for my mother's step father in his Italian restaurant. It was very clean but still there were practices I realized later were unsanitary.
Do I eat out? Rarely.
"Down and Out in London and Paris" also will inspire you to cook at home.
Or Anthony Bourdain's "Kitchen Confidential" for a more contemporary, behind the scenes expose'.

The main reason I prefer to cook and enjoy food at home is a sanitary one.
You see, I used to work in the restaurant business for many years and I'll be the first to tell you what I've seen behind the wall of a kitchen is not too savory.
The people who work at chain places are some of the worst yet even the better or more upscale, expensive restaurants have some problems.
I know that my food was stored and handled properly, washed, prepared on clean cutting boards/counter tops/knives with no cross contamination, on and on. The restaurant business has many workers and some can have quite disgusting habits and dirty, filthy premises, lack of training and NO PAID SICK DAYS! So employees come to work in kitchens everywhere to prepare your food who are very ill. Sneezing and coughing and runny noses and all.
I'm surprised more people don't get sick from eating out. Maybe they would if they knew the truth of matter. I like clean, safe and ultimately healthier food made at home for myself and family and friends. It always tastes much better too. I'm tired of paying for expensive, inferior meals at most places. As a rule of thumb avoid any place with a deep fry-o-lator machine.

I, respectfully, disagree about his defiance of Federal law and confusing the system and probate judges. Who gets hurt again? the lgbt community.

I'm not sure what you mean by, "misses the broader point." Moore's point is that he disagrees with marriage equality and doesn't accept the country's laws.

Robed ayatollah, perfect description of Roy Moore. Thinks he's above the US Constitution's Supreme Court which IS the supreme law of the land.
US Supreme Court justice nominations are made by the duly elected president of the United States with the advice and consent of US senators duly elected by state voters. Hey, it's all set out in our founding governmental document: the Constitution which was duly adopted by voters in Early America. It's our American democratic republic system of government.

Gerald:  American Legislative Exchange Council, a collaboration of mostly Republican state legislators and mostly pro-Republican big businesses, whose proceedings are mostly secret.  ALEC writes (in secret meetings) model legislation that is often adopted word for word, or with slight changes, by many states, usually Republican ones.  Their model legislation is  pro-business and anti-union, to an extreme.  Lately they have also been writing right-wing get-out-the-vote legislation like anti-gay and vote-limiting draft bills.  You probably think  I'm making this up or exaggerating.  I wish that were true.  Look them up.  Find old NYT articles about them.

It is truly a shame that no one from the Dixi-publicans are willing to move an inch to give equality to all their citizens. To them, it seems that the Federal laws and the Constitution mean little or nothing. This is the heart of the HATE that pervades the South and is taking over all of the GOTP.. They seem totally oblivious to the fact that a rule by 56% for the good of the top 1% to 5% is totally bad for the survival and good health of the nation.
